Text: For the choirmaster. According to Jeduthun. Of Asaph. A Psalm.
Context: This introductory note indicates the musical setting and authorship, setting the stage for the Psalm's content.

Text: I cried out to God for help; I cried out to God to hear me.
Context: The psalmist is expressing distress and seeking God's attention.

Text: When I was in distress, I sought the Lord; at night I stretched out untiring hands, and I would not be comforted.
Context: The psalmist describes continuous, restless seeking of God during a time of great trouble.

Text: I remembered you, God, and I groaned; I meditated, and my spirit grew faint.
Context: Selah
column7: The psalmist is troubled upon reflection of God, indicating deep spiritual unrest.

Text: You kept my eyes from closing; I was too troubled to speak.
Context: The psalmist experiences insomnia and speechlessness due to the intensity of distress.

Text: I thought about the former days, the years of long ago;
Context: The psalmist is reflecting on the past, possibly suggesting a better time compared to the present woes.

Text: I remembered my music in the night. My heart meditated and my spirit asked:
Context: Nostalgic recollection of music during the night implies a search for comfort.

Text: Will the Lord reject forever? Will he never show his favor again?
Context: Psalmist is questioning God's favor and presence, implying a sense of abandonment.

Text: Has his unfailing love vanished forever? Has his promise failed for all time?
Context: A doubting concern over whether God's love and promises have permanently ceased.

Text: Has God forgotten to be merciful? Has he in anger withheld his compassion?
Context: Selah
column7: The psalmist questions God's mercy and compassion, possibly feeling that God's anger is present instead.

Text: Then I thought, "To this I will appeal: the years when the Most High stretched out his right hand."
Context: In the midst of questioning, the psalmist resolves to appeal to a time when God's power was evident.

Text: I will remember the deeds of the LORD; yes, I will remember your wonders of old.
Context: The psalmist shifts to recalling God's mighty works in the past as a source of comfort.

Text: I will meditate on all your works and consider all your mighty deeds.
Context: A deliberate decision to focus on God's acts and achievements.

Text: Your ways, God, are holy. What god is so great as our God?
Context: The psalmist expresses awe and reverence for God's unique holiness and greatness.

Text: You are the God who performs miracles; you display your power among the peoples.
Context: Recognition of God's miraculous works and the demonstration of His power to the world.

Text: With your mighty arm you redeemed your people, the descendants of Jacob and Joseph.
Context: Selah
column7: Affirmation of God's past redemption of Israel, reflecting gratitude for God's intervention.

Text: The waters saw you, God, the waters saw you and writhed; the very depths were convulsed.
Context: A poetic depiction of nature's reaction to God's presence, possibly referring to the parting of the Red Sea.

Text: The clouds poured down water, the heavens resounded with thunder; your arrows flashed back and forth.
Context: Descriptive imagery of a theophany, representing God's power in a storm.

Text: Your thunder was heard in the whirlwind, your lightning lit up the world; the earth trembled and quaked.
Context: Continuation of the powerful storm imagery, emphasizing God's majesty and the earth's response.

Text: Your path led through the sea, your way through the mighty waters, though your footprints were not seen.
Context: An allusion to God's miraculous passage through the Red Sea, highlighting the mysterious nature of His works.

Text: You led your people like a flock by the hand of Moses and Aaron.
Context: Conclusion with an affirmation of God's guidance of Israel, symbolized by the leadership of Moses and Aaron.
